private_information: I can perform six parameterized actions: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, and tightfisted. Each action takes object parameters as described in the public information.
I can simulate execution of a grounded action sequence given an initial fact set and report which preconditions hold and which effects apply.
player.goal: Validate and simulate candidate action plans on given initial states and produce a grounded step-by-step execution trace with resulting facts.

private_information: I collect and normalize raw initial facts from scenario statements. I map object identifiers and list all atoms present in the initial state.
I preserve two recorded scenarios from the human statements and can present them as distinct labeled initial states.
observer.goal: Produce canonicalized initial state descriptions for scenarios and highlight differences between them.

private_information: I audit temporal and causal consistency. I detect bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens and post-hoc penalties and propose concrete eliminations or normalizations.
I ensure that action preconditions and effects are temporally coherent and that the plan does not rely on implicit side effects or hidden tokens.
auditor.goal: Provide an audit report that removes bookkeeping shortcuts and produces explicit causal links and normalization suggestions so plans can be encoded without post-hoc assumptions.

private_information: I integrate reports from other agents and produce the final planning artifacts for a FastDownwards solver.
I must keep each agent's actions distinct and encode the combined model as a single PDDL domain and one or more PDDL problem files targeting FastDownwards compatibility.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate player simulation traces, observer canonical initial states, and auditor normalizations to output a PDDL domain and PDDL problem compatible with FastDownwards that achieves the requested goals.

public_information: Actions available and their templates. All templates use positional parameters named object_0, object_1, object_2 and optionally object_3 for wretched.

paltry requires: hand object_0, cats object_1, texture object_2, vase object_0 object_1, next object_1 object_2. paltry effects: add next object_0 object_2. paltry negative effects: remove vase object_0 object_1.

sip requires: hand object_0, cats object_1, texture object_2, next object_0 object_2, next object_1 object_2. sip effects: add vase object_0 object_1. sip negative effects: remove next object_0 object_2.

clip requires: hand object_0, sneeze object_1, texture object_2, next object_1 object_2, next object_0 object_2. clip effects: add vase object_0 object_1. clip negative effects: remove next object_0 object_2.

wretched requires: sneeze object_0, texture object_1, texture object_2, stupendous object_3, next object_0 object_1, collect object_1 object_3, collect object_2 object_3. wretched effects: add next object_0 object_2. wretched negative effects: remove next object_0 object_1.
memory requires: cats object_0, spring object_1, spring object_2, next object_0 object_1. memory effects: add next object_0 object_2. memory negative effects: remove next object_0 object_1.

tightfisted requires: hand object_0, sneeze object_1, texture object_2, next object_1 object_2, vase object_0 object_1. tightfisted effects: add next object_0 object_2. tightfisted negative effects: remove vase object_0 object_1.
Two recorded scenarios follow. Scenario labels are scenario_A and scenario_B.

scenario_A initial facts: cats object_0, collect object_5 object_1, collect object_6 object_1, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, hand object_9, next object_0 object_7, next object_3 object_5, next object_4 object_7, next object_9 object_7, sneeze object_3, sneeze object_4, spring object_5, spring object_7, stupendous object_1, stupendous object_2, texture object_5, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8.
scenario_A suggested plan: clip object_9 object_4 object_7; wretched object_4 object_7 object_8 object_2; tightfisted object_9 object_4 object_8.

scenario_B initial facts: cats object_0, collect object_5 object_1, collect object_6 object_1, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, hand object_9, next object_0 object_5, next object_3 object_5, next object_4 object_8, next object_9 object_6, sneeze object_3, sneeze object_4, spring object_5, spring object_7, stupendous object_1, stupendous object_2, texture object_5, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8.
Note that object indices appear across scenarios and that auditors must remove or replace bookkeeping shortcuts before encoding into PDDL. Do not assume hidden tokens. Make all causal links explicit.

report.system_prompt: You are the player agent. Simulate grounded action sequences on the provided scenario initial states. For each grounded action, check every required precondition against the canonical initial facts or the state resulting from previous steps and report which preconditions are satisfied and which fail. Show the deterministic add and delete effects that result from each action when it is applied. Do not emit PDDL. Produce a clear execution trace and a final state for each simulated plan.
report.prompt: Your name is player. Use environment public information to access action templates and scenario descriptions. Given a scenario label and a candidate grounded plan, validate each step against the scenario initial facts and previously applied effects. Provide a step-by-step grounded execution trace and the final atom set after the plan. If information is missing, report the missing atoms and do not assume hidden facts.

report.system_prompt: You are the observer agent. Your responsibility is to canonicalize raw initial facts from scenario statements. Normalize object identifiers and produce a consistent listing of the initial atoms for each scenario. Highlight any naming collisions and list all atoms that mention 'collect', 'hand', 'next', 'sneeze', 'spring', 'stupendous', 'texture', and 'cats'. Do not emit PDDL.
report.prompt: Your name is observer. Read the public information scenarios labeled scenario_A and scenario_B. For each scenario, produce a canonical initial state with a sorted list of ground atoms. Note differences and commonalities between scenarios. Point out any atoms that could be bookkeeping shortcuts that require auditor attention.

audit.system_prompt: You are the auditor agent specializing in temporal and causal consistency. Inspect canonicalized initial states and execution traces. Detect bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens, post-hoc penalties, or implicit assumptions. Propose concrete normalization steps such as introducing explicit collect actions, expanding implicit tokens into explicit atom sets, or removing ambiguous atoms. Provide a transformed, bookkeeping-free representation of states and a list of recommended modeling changes that ensure causal clarity. Do not emit PDDL.
audit.prompt: Your name is auditor. Take the observer_report and player_report. Verify that every causal link in the player_report is supported by explicit atoms in the canonicalized initial state or by effects from prior steps. Where the plan relies on implicit bookkeeping, replace those shortcuts with explicit atoms and actions and explain the replacement. Output an audit_report that includes the normalized initial states and modeling recommendations.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL modeling and the FastDownwards planner target. Integrate canonical initial states, execution traces, and auditor normalizations into a single consistent PDDL domain and one or more PDDL problem files. Keep agent actions distinct by prefixing action names if needed. Ensure the domain uses constructs supported by FastDownwards, preferably STRIPS or ADL constructs widely accepted by FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem>. The produced PDDL must be directly usable by FastDownwards without hidden assumptions.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Combine the observer_report canonical initial states, the player_report execution trace, and the auditor_report modeling normalizations. Resolve naming conflicts, keep actions from different agents distinct, and encode the final domain and problem aimed at the FastDownwards solver. Enclose the domain text between <domain></domain> tags and the problem file between <problem></problem>. If multiple scenarios are supported, produce one PDDL problem per scenario and label them clearly.
